subject: Re: [junit] Re: Any plans to revamp junit?
msgSnippet: ... Let s see.... I hear all serious people have their own runners anyway. if x is a person, and S x is x is serious and R x is x has his own test
messageBody:
Vlad Roubtsov wrote:
> > > Is there any reason to use the official JUnit
> > > distribution for its testcase runner(s) vs just
> > its
> > > TestCase interface? I hear all serious people have
> > > their own runners anyway.
> >
> > Rudeness objection. I use the basic test runners and
> > I am /quite/ serious.
>
> Sorry, your objection seems to be flawed logically.

Let's see....

"I hear all serious people have their own runners anyway."

if x is a person, and S x is "x is serious" and R x is "x has his own
test runner", then the claim is...

forall x (S x -> R x)

By the law of specialization, in particular, if j means yours truly (and
yes, I am a person), then

S j -> R j

However, I don't have my own test runner, so

~R j and (S j -> R j)
<=> ~R j and (~R j -> ~S j) [negating the consequence]
=> ~S j [modus ponens]

According to my reading of the situation, the result of my not having my
own test runner is that I am not serious.

The problem is, I am /quite/ serious, having spent a year writing about
it and all that. Say whatever you want about the quality of the work,
whoever spends a year writing on a topic is almost certainly serious
about it.

> You might be serious and use your own test runner.
> This does not preclude your also using the basic test
> runners.

I don't see at all how this follows from the preceding. The claim is
that if I am serious, then I have my own test runner, but I don't have
my own test runner, so that implies that I am not serious. That is my
objection. I'm quite serious.

> The fact that there is apparent need for better test
> runners, that basic runners are not used by all IDEs
> or ANT makes my question legitimate, I think.

Oh yes, just not the claim that "all serious people have their own test
runners."

> JUnit is the de facto standard, but it's the TestCase
> interface, not anything else. Or am I mistaken?

The framework is what's standard, and not the test runners. Correct.
